Name: Jeffrey D. Sachs
info: Jeffrey David Sachs is an American economist and public policy analyst, currently a professor at Columbia University and director of the Center for Sustainable Development. He has made significant contributions to sustainable and economic development, serving as a special advisor to the UN Secretary-General from 2001 to 2018 and as an advocate for the Sustainable Development Goals. Sachs co-founded the Millennium Promise Alliance and directed the UN Millennium Project, focusing on poverty alleviation and health policy. He has authored several influential books and received numerous awards for his work, which has sparked both acclaim and criticism, particularly regarding his economic strategies in post-communist countries.

Name: Joseph S. Nye
info: Joseph Samuel Nye Jr. was an influential American political scientist known for co-founding the international relations theory of neoliberalism alongside Robert Keohane, particularly through their seminal work "Power and Interdependence." He introduced the concept of soft power and the idea of smart power, which emphasizes the strategic combination of hard and soft power. Nye served as the Dean of the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University and held the title of University Distinguished Service Professor, emeritus. His contributions to international relations have earned him numerous accolades, including the Woodrow Wilson Prize and the Order of the Rising Sun from Japan. Nye was actively involved in various policy boards and commissions, including the Foreign Affairs Policy Board, and remained a prominent figure in discussions on global politics until his passing in 2025.

Name: Howard A. Stone
info: N/A

Name: Lawrence Katz
info: N/A

Name: Zhigang Suo (锁志刚）
info: N/A

Name: Jeffrey M. Karp
info: Jeffrey Karp is a Canadian biomedical engineer and Professor of Medicine at Harvard Medical School, affiliated with Brigham and Women's Hospital and the Harvard Stem Cell Institute, as well as the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He earned his degree in chemical engineering from McGill University and a Ph.D. in Chemical and Biomedical Engineering from the University of Toronto. Karp's research focuses on medical adhesives inspired by gecko adhesion and has led to the founding of several companies, including Gecko Biomedical and Frequency Therapeutics. He has received multiple awards for his mentoring and innovation, including recognition as one of Technology Review's top innovators under 35 and the Young Investigator award from the Society for Biomaterials.

Name: David Cutler
info: N/A

Name: Ali Khademhosseini
info: Ali Khademhosseini is an Iranian-born Canadian-American engineer and entrepreneur, currently serving as the CEO and director of the Terasaki Institute for Biomedical Innovation in Los Angeles. He previously held a multi-departmental professorship at UCLA, where he contributed significantly to bioengineering, radiology, and chemical engineering. Khademhosseini's research focuses on biomaterials, tissue engineering, and microfluidics, with notable contributions including the development of Gelatin Methacryloyl (GelMA) hydrogels and multi-organ-on-a-chip platforms. He has published around 1,000 scientific articles, earning over 148,000 citations, and has received numerous awards for his interdisciplinary work, including the Materials Research Society Mid Career Research Award and the Mustafa Prize. In addition to his academic achievements, he is active in technology translation, having co-founded companies like Obsidio Medical and Omeat Inc.

Name: Nadine Gaab
info: The Gaab Lab at Harvard Graduate School of Education specializes in developmental cognitive neuroscience, focusing on language and reading development across typical and atypical learning trajectories. Their research investigates the neurobiological origins of reading skills and learning disabilities, aiming to inform educational practices and policies through innovative methodologies and community outreach.

Name: Daniel J. Jacob
info: N/A

Name: Peter Libby
info: Peter Libby is an American physician specializing in atherosclerosis, cardiology, and preventive cardiology. He currently serves as the Mallinckrodt Professor of Medicine at Harvard Medical School and is affiliated with Brigham and Women's Hospital. His notable contributions to the field have significantly advanced the understanding of cardiovascular diseases.

Name: Dani Rodrik
info: Dani Rodrik is a prominent Turkish economist and the Ford Foundation Professor of International Political Economy at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government. His research focuses on international economics, economic development, and political economy, particularly exploring the dynamics of effective economic policy and government success. Notable works include "The Globalization Paradox" and "Economics Rules," and he has contributed significantly to academic discourse as a joint editor-in-chief of the journal Global Policy. Rodrik has received numerous accolades, including the Leontief Prize for Advancing the Frontiers of Economic Thought and an honorary doctorate from Erasmus University Rotterdam, and he is affiliated with several prestigious economic research organizations.

Name: George M Whitesides
info: N/A

Name: Seok Hyun (Andy) Yun
info: N/A

Name: Lisa Feldman Barrett
info: N/A

Name: Yi Cui
info: N/A

Name: Stephen Boyd
info: Stephen Boyd, born William Millar on July 4, 1931, in Northern Ireland, was a prominent actor known for his compelling performances in film during the late 1950s and 1960s. He gained significant acclaim for his role as the antagonist Messala in the epic film Ben-Hur, which earned him a Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor. Boyd's career included notable appearances in films such as The Man Who Never Was, The Bravados, and Fantastic Voyage, showcasing his versatility in both heroic and villainous roles. He received a second Golden Globe nomination for his performance in Billy Rose's Jumbo. Boyd's contributions to cinema were marked by his ability to portray complex characters, and he remains celebrated for his impactful performances until his untimely death on June 2, 1977.

Name: Jay Bhattacharya
info: Jayanta Bhattacharya is an American physician-scientist and health economist, currently serving as the 18th director of the National Institutes of Health since 2025. Previously, he was a professor at Stanford University, where he focused on the economics of health care and held various academic appointments, including director of the Center for Demography and Economics of Health and Aging. Bhattacharya gained prominence for his opposition to COVID-19 lockdowns and mask mandates, co-authoring the Great Barrington Declaration, which advocated for focused protection of vulnerable populations. He has received recognition for his research contributions and has been involved in significant public health discussions during the pandemic.

Name: Karl Deisseroth
info: Karl Alexander Deisseroth is an American scientist and the D.H. Chen Foundation Professor of Bioengineering and Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences at Stanford University. He is renowned for his pioneering work in optogenetics and hydrogel-tissue chemistry, notably developing technologies such as CLARITY and STARmap, which have advanced the understanding of neural circuits in health and disease. Deisseroth has received numerous prestigious awards, including the Kyoto Prize and the Breakthrough Prize in Life Sciences, recognizing his significant contributions to neuroscience. He has been a member of the US National Academy of Engineering, the US National Academy of Sciences, and the US National Academy of Medicine, and continues to lead research at Stanford while serving as an attending physician at Stanford Hospital and Clinics.

Name: Parviz Moin
info: Parviz Moin is a prominent fluid dynamicist and the Franklin P. and Caroline M. Johnson Professor of Mechanical Engineering at Stanford University. He has made significant contributions to the field through his pioneering work in direct numerical simulation and large eddy simulation techniques for turbulence research. Moin is the founding director of the Center for Turbulence Research, a collaboration between NASA and Stanford, and has served as an editor for the Annual Review of Fluid Mechanics. His accolades include the NASA Exceptional Scientific Achievement Medal, the Lawrence Sperry Award, and election to the National Academy of Engineering and the National Academy of Sciences.

Name: Subhasish Mitra
info: Subhasish Mitra is a professor of Computer Science and Electrical Engineering at Stanford University, where he leads the Stanford Robust Systems Group and the Computation Focus Area of the Stanford SystemX Alliance. His research interests encompass Robust Computing, NanoSystems, Electronic Design Automation, and Neurosciences. Mitra has received numerous accolades, including the Intel Achievement Award, the Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers, and recognition as a Fellow of both the IEEE and ACM. He holds the William E. Ayer Professorship in Electrical Engineering and teaches digital systems design at Stanford.

Name: James J. Gross
info: James J. Gross is an American psychologist and the Ernest R. Hilgard Professor of Psychology at Stanford University, where he leads the Stanford Center for Affective Science and the Stanford Psychophysiology Laboratory. He is renowned for developing the process model of emotion regulation, a significant framework in affective science that outlines how emotions can be regulated through various strategies. Gross has co-authored over 650 scientific publications and has served as the editor of the Handbook of Emotion Regulation. His contributions to the field have been recognized with numerous awards, including the Grawemeyer Award in Psychology and honorary doctorates from prestigious institutions. He continues to influence the study of emotion and its regulation through his research and teaching at Stanford University.

Name: Noah D. Goodman
info: N/A

Name: Richard N. Zare
info: Richard Neil Zare is the Marguerite Blake Wilbur Professor in Natural Science and a Professor of Chemistry at Stanford University. He is renowned for his contributions to physical and analytical chemistry, particularly in the development of laser-induced fluorescence (LIF), which has applications in various fields including molecular biology and astrophysics. Zare has mentored over 150 PhD students and is a strong advocate for women in science. He has published extensively, including a widely used textbook on angular momentum in quantum systems, and has served on significant boards such as the National Science Board of the National Science Foundation. His current research interests include mass spectrometry and astrobiology, with notable work involving the analysis of Martian meteorites.

Name: Robert Tibshirani
info: Robert Tibshirani is a professor in the Departments of Statistics and Biomedical Data Science at Stanford University, having previously served at the University of Toronto from 1985 to 1998. He is renowned for developing statistical tools for complex data analysis, particularly in genomics and proteomics, with notable contributions including the Lasso method and Significance Analysis of Microarrays. Tibshirani has received numerous accolades, including the COPSS Presidents' Award, the E.W.R. Steacie Memorial Fellowship, and election to the Royal Society and the National Academy of Sciences. He has coauthored several influential books and approximately 250 scientific articles, often collaborating with Trevor Hastie.

Name: Russ B Altman
info: Russ Biagio Altman is an American professor at Stanford University, specializing in bioengineering, genetics, medicine, and biomedical data science, with a courtesy appointment in computer science. He holds an A.B. from Harvard College, a Ph.D. in medical information sciences, and an M.D. from Stanford. Altman's research focuses on the intersection of computing and medicine, particularly in understanding drug action and human genetic variation's impact on drug response, contributing to projects like PharmGKB and FEATURE. He has received numerous awards, including the U.S. Presidential Early Career Award and the ISCB Outstanding Contributions Award, and is a member of the National Academy of Medicine. Currently, he serves as an associate director at the Stanford Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence and is clinically active in pharmacogenomics at Stanford Healthcare.

Name: Mykel J. Kochenderfer
info: N/A

Name: Jelena Vuckovic
info: N/A

Name: Jeffrey T. Hancock
info: Jeffrey T. Hancock is a communication and psychology researcher and professor at Stanford University's College of Communication, known for his significant contributions to the study of deception, trust in technology, and the psychology of social media. He has published over 80 journal articles and founded the Stanford Social Media Lab, which investigates various aspects of social media's impact on interpersonal relationships and societal issues. Hancock's research has garnered attention from major media outlets, and he has delivered influential talks, including a TED presentation on the future of lying. In 2024, he faced controversy over his use of AI in a court filing related to deepfake legislation, which ultimately led to the exclusion of his testimony due to credibility concerns.

Name: Marco Pavone
info: N/A

Name: Hai Wang

Name: David A B Miller
info: N/A

Name: Juan J. Alonso
info: N/A

Name: Nick Bloom
info: Nick Bloom was an Australian rules footballer known for his time with St Kilda in the Victorian Football League. He played during a significant era in the sport and contributed to the team's competitive spirit. Bloom's career in the VFL is remembered for his dedication to the game and his impact on the field. He passed away on June 7, 2011.

Name: Yet-Ming Chiang
info: Yet-Ming Chiang is a Taiwanese-American materials scientist and engineer, currently serving as the Kyocera Professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He has made significant contributions to the development of new materials for energy storage and power, particularly in the context of battery technology and climate technology. Chiang is the author of over 200 peer-reviewed publications and holds more than 30 patents. He was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 2009 and has received several awards, including the R&D 100 Award and the Ross Coffin Purdy Award. In addition to his academic work, he has founded or consulted for multiple companies in the materials and energy sectors.

Name: James J Collins
info: The Collins Lab at MIT focuses on synthetic biology and systems biology, utilizing engineering principles and artificial intelligence to design synthetic gene circuits, develop novel diagnostics and therapeutics, and discover new classes of antibiotics. Their work aims to address challenges in antibiotic resistance and enhance the design process in synthetic biology.

Name: Christopher Cummins
info: Professor Christopher C. Cummins leads a research group at MIT focused on synthetic chemistry, particularly in the development of new methods for inorganic synthesis and the exploration of small molecule reactions. His work includes CO2 reduction for renewable energy, uranium chemistry, and the design of innovative ligands for enhancing metal-based reactions and catalysis.

Name: Moungi G. Bawendi
info: Moungi Bawendi is an American-Tunisian-French chemist and the Lester Wolfe Professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He is renowned for his pioneering work in the chemical production of high-quality quantum dots, which has significant implications for various technological applications. Bawendi's notable contributions include the development of standardized methods for quantum dot synthesis, particularly the hot-injection method, which allows for precise control over the size and properties of these nanocrystals. He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2023 for his groundbreaking discoveries in this field, among other accolades such as the Sloan Research Fellowship and the Sackler Prize in Physical Chemistry.

Name: Brian L. Wardle
info: N/A

Name: James Evans
info: N/A

Name: Tao Pan
info: N/A

Name: Heinrich Jaeger
info: N/A

Name: Richard Thaler
info: Richard H. Thaler, born on September 12, 1945, is an influential American economist and the Charles R. Walgreen Distinguished Service Professor of Behavioral Science and Economics at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business. A pioneer in the field of behavioral economics, Thaler's notable contributions include his collaboration with prominent figures like Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky, and his work on concepts such as "nudges" and "choice architecture," which aim to improve decision-making processes. He was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences in 2017 for his groundbreaking research that bridges economic and psychological analyses of decision-making. Thaler is also known for his popular books, including "Nudge," co-authored with Cass Sunstein, and "Misbehaving," which chronicles the development of behavioral economics. He was president of the American Economic Association in 2015 and was elected to the National Academy of Sciences in 2018.

Name: Scott A. Snyder
info: Scott Snyder is an American comic book author born on January 15, 1976, known for his significant contributions to the comic book industry, particularly with DC Comics. He gained acclaim for his work on series such as American Vampire, Batman, and Swamp Thing, and is recognized for co-creating characters like The Batman Who Laughs and the Court of Owls. His notable works include the critically acclaimed Batman run that began in 2011, as well as creator-owned titles like Wytches and Nocterra. Snyder has received numerous accolades, including three Eisner Awards and a Harvey Award. He is currently affiliated with comiXology Originals and continues to develop new projects through his imprint Best Jackett Press.

Name: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
info: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg is a Mexican-American economist and the Glen A. Lloyd Distinguished Service Professor in the Kenneth C. Griffin Department of Economics at the University of Chicago. Previously, he held the Theodore A. Wells '29 Professorship at Princeton University and has also been a faculty member at Stanford University. His research encompasses macroeconomics, international trade, and urban and regional economics, focusing on topics such as city structure, economic activity distribution, wage inequality due to offshoring, and firm dynamics. Rossi-Hansberg is a research fellow at the NBER and CEPR, a Fellow of the Econometric Society since 2017, and serves as the lead editor of the Journal of Political Economy.

Name: Robert Langer
info: Robert Samuel Langer Jr. is an influential American biotechnologist, chemical engineer, and inventor, born on August 29, 1948. He is an Institute Professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he has made significant contributions to drug delivery systems and tissue engineering, holding over 1,400 patents and authoring more than 1,600 scientific papers. Langer's pioneering work includes the development of controlled release systems and innovative techniques for treating diseases such as cancer and diabetes. He has received numerous prestigious awards, including the U.S. National Medal of Science and the National Medal of Technology and Innovation, and is recognized as one of the most cited engineers in history. Langer continues to lead the largest biomedical engineering lab at MIT, driving advancements in regenerative medicine and biotechnology.

Name: Mark Cutkosky
info: N/A

Name: Gretchen C. Daily
info: Gretchen C. Daily is an American environmental scientist and tropical ecologist, recognized for her significant contributions to understanding humanity's relationship with nature and the valuation of ecosystem services. She is the co-founder and faculty director of the Natural Capital Project at Stanford University, which aims to integrate the values of nature into global decision-making processes. Daily holds the position of Bing Professor of Environmental Science in the Department of Biology at Stanford and directs the Center for Conservation Biology. Her notable works include "Nature's Services: Societal Dependence on Natural Ecosystems" and "The New Economy of Nature," which have influenced conservation policy worldwide. Daily is an elected fellow of several prestigious academies, including the U.S. National Academy of Sciences, and continues to advance interdisciplinary research on biodiversity and ecosystem services.

Name: Michael C. Frank
info: Michael Frank was a German American pioneer, newspaper editor, and politician, born on December 12, 1804, in Virgil, New York. He is best known as the first Mayor of Kenosha, Wisconsin, and is recognized as the father of Wisconsin public schools for his pivotal role in establishing free public education in the state. Frank co-founded the Southport Telegraph, which supported various social reform movements, and he was instrumental in drafting the public school code adopted by the Wisconsin legislature in 1849. He served in various public roles, including as a member of the Wisconsin State Assembly and as a Regent of the University of Wisconsin, before retiring from public life in Kenosha, where he passed away on December 26, 1894.

Name: Tatsunori Hashimoto
info: N/A

Name: Ram Rajagopal
info: N/A

Name: Steven J. Davis
info: Steven Davis is a Northern Irish former professional footballer born on January 1, 1985, who played as a midfielder. He is renowned for being the most capped player for Northern Ireland, with 140 international appearances and 13 goals, and captained the national team during UEFA Euro 2016. Davis began his career at Aston Villa, where he earned multiple player awards, before transferring to Fulham and then to Rangers, where he won several Scottish league titles and cups. After a successful stint at Southampton, he returned to Rangers in 2019, winning additional titles before announcing his retirement in January 2024. Throughout his career, he made a total of 371 appearances for Rangers, scoring 28 goals.

Name: Matthew Kanan
info: N/A

Name: John C Mitchell
info: N/A

Name: Russ Poldrack
info: The Poldrack Lab at Stanford focuses on understanding the relationship between brain function and adaptive human behaviors through functional neuroimaging, cognitive psychology, and computational modeling, while also promoting transparency and reproducibility in neuroscience research.

Name: John Pauly
info: N/A

Name: Charles I. Jones
info: N/A

Name: Edward I. Solomon
info: Edward Solomon was an English composer, conductor, orchestrator, and pianist, born on July 25, 1855, in Lambeth, London. He is best known for his contributions to comic opera, particularly through works produced for the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, including his notable piece The Nautch Girl (1891). Solomon collaborated frequently with Henry Pottinger Stephens, resulting in successful operas such as Billee Taylor (1880) and Claude Duval (1881). Despite a tumultuous personal life, including a bigamous marriage to actress Lillian Russell, Solomon's musical legacy includes numerous operas and ballads. He passed away at the young age of 39 on January 22, 1895, due to typhoid fever.

Name: Paul Milgrom
info: Paul Robert Milgrom is an American economist and the Shirley and Leonard Ely Professor of Humanities and Sciences at Stanford University, where he has been since 1987. He specializes in game theory, particularly auction theory and pricing strategies, and is a Senior Fellow at the Stanford Institute for Economic Research. Milgrom was awarded the 2020 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences for his contributions to auction theory and the development of new auction formats, alongside Robert B. Wilson. His notable works include the design of the FCC auction protocol for cellular frequencies and the broadcast incentive auction. He is also a co-founder of Auctionomics, which won a technical Emmy Award in 2024 for its innovations in spectrum auction design.

Name: Anshul Kundaje
info: N/A

Name: Jaimie M. Henderson

Name: Sarah Heilshorn
info: N/A

Name: Trevor Hastie
info: Trevor John Hastie is an American statistician and computer scientist, currently the John A. Overdeck Professor of Mathematical Sciences and Professor of Statistics at Stanford University. He is renowned for his contributions to applied statistics, particularly in machine learning, data mining, and bioinformatics, and has authored influential works such as The Elements of Statistical Learning. Hastie has received numerous accolades, including being elected to the National Academy of Sciences and the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences, and is a Fellow of several prestigious statistical societies. His prolific research output includes around 125 scientific articles and several key publications in statistical learning.

Name: Euan A. Ashley
info: Euan Angus Ashley is a Scottish physician and scientist based at Stanford University, where he serves as the Arthur L. Bloomfield Chair of the Department of Medicine. He is a pioneer in the field of precision medicine, notably leading the first medical interpretation of a human genome and developing frameworks for family-based medical genome analysis. Ashley founded the Stanford Center for Inherited Cardiovascular Disease and has contributed significantly to cardiovascular science, including advancements in heart transplant donation after cardiac death. He has received numerous accolades, including the National Innovation Award from the American Heart Association and the Guggenheim Fellowship in 2023, and has authored over 400 peer-reviewed publications as well as notable books such as "The Genome Odyssey."

Name: Richard A. Flavell
info: Richard Anthony Flavell is an English molecular biologist and Sterling Professor of Immunobiology at Yale School of Medicine, where he focuses on innate and adaptive immunity, T cell tolerance and activation, apoptosis, and T cell differentiation using transgenic and gene-targeted mice. He is also an investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. Flavell earned his Ph.D. from the University of Hull in 1970 and has held various academic and leadership positions, including at the University of Amsterdam and Biogen. He received the Vilcek Prize in Biomedical Science in 2013 and an honorary doctorate from the University of Hull in 2016, and he is an honorary member of the British Society for Immunology.

Name: Peter C. B. Phillips
info: Peter Mark Andrew Phillips is a British businessman born on 15 November 1977, the son of Princess Anne and Mark Phillips. He graduated from the University of Exeter with a degree in Sports Science and has held various roles in the sports management and corporate sectors, including managing director at SEL UK. Notably, he organized the "Patron's Lunch" for Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday and has been involved in high-profile events such as the Rugby League Challenge Cup Final. Phillips has received several honors, including the Queen Elizabeth II Golden Jubilee Medal and the King Charles III Coronation Medal. He is currently affiliated with SEL UK and has been active in royal family engagements.

Name: John Krystal
info: N/A

Name: Gerald I Shulman
info: N/A

Name: F. Perry Wilson, MD MSCE
info: Dr. F. Perry Wilson is a nephrology and internal medicine specialist at Yale School of Medicine, known for his extensive research contributions with over 100 peer-reviewed publications and for teaching a highly-rated online course on medical research. He is also a prominent medical commentator on platforms like Medscape and CNN.

Name: Anna C Nobre
info: Anna Christina Nobre, known as Kia Nobre, is a Brazilian and British cognitive neuroscientist currently serving as the Wu Tsai Professor at Yale University. She has made significant contributions to the understanding of how the brain prioritizes and selects information, with notable research milestones including the discovery of brain areas specialized for word recognition and face processing, as well as pioneering studies on temporal expectations and selective attention. Nobre has received numerous accolades, including election to the British Academy and the National Academy of Sciences, and has been honored with awards such as the MRC Suffrage Science Award and the Fred Kavli Distinguished Career Contributions Award. She previously held various leadership roles at the University of Oxford, where she was the first female Tutorial Fellow in a science discipline and directed the Oxford Centre for Human Brain Activity.

Name: Ruslan Medzhitov
info: Ruslan Medzhitov is a professor of immunobiology and dermatology at the Yale School of Medicine and an investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. His research primarily investigates the innate immune system, inflammatory responses, and host-pathogen interactions, notably contributing to the discovery of Toll-like receptor 4. Medzhitov has received numerous accolades, including election to the National Academy of Sciences in 2010 and the Sterling Professor title at Yale. He has also been honored with prestigious awards such as the William Coley Award and the Shaw Prize in Life Science and Medicine. Currently, he continues his work at Yale University, where he also collaborates with his wife, Akiko Iwasaki.

Name: James S. Duncan
info: N/A

Name: Hongyu Zhao
info: N/A

Name: A. Douglas Stone
info: N/A

Name: John Hopfield
info: John Joseph Hopfield is an American physicist and emeritus professor at Princeton University, renowned for his pioneering work on associative neural networks, particularly the development of the Hopfield network in 1982, which revitalized interest in artificial intelligence. He has made significant contributions across various fields including condensed matter physics, statistical physics, and biophysics, with notable works on excitons, kinetic proofreading, and the critical brain hypothesis. In 2024, he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics alongside Geoffrey Hinton for foundational discoveries in machine learning with artificial neural networks. Throughout his career, Hopfield has received numerous accolades, including the MacArthur Fellowship and the Oliver E. Buckley Prize, and he continues to influence the field of computational neuroscience.

Name: Jianqing Fan
info: Jianqing Fan is a prominent Chinese statistician, financial econometrician, and data scientist, currently serving as the Frederick L. Moore '18 Professor of Finance and a professor in Operations Research and Financial Engineering, Statistics, and Machine Learning at Princeton University. He has made significant contributions to high-dimensional statistics, machine learning, and financial econometrics, authoring over 300 articles and coauthoring several influential books, including "Local Polynomial Modeling" and "Statistical Foundations of Data Science." Fan has held editorial positions in numerous prestigious journals and has received multiple awards for his work, including the COPSS Presidents' Award and the Guy Medal in Silver. He has also served as president of the Institute of Mathematical Statistics and the International Chinese Statistical Association, and he continues to direct research labs at Princeton University.

Name: H Sebastian Seung
info: N/A

Name: Paul J. Steinhardt
info: Paul Joseph Steinhardt is an American theoretical physicist born on December 25, 1952, known for his significant contributions to cosmology and condensed matter physics. He is currently the Albert Einstein Professor in Science at Princeton University, where he is affiliated with the Departments of Physics and Astrophysical Sciences. Steinhardt is recognized for developing new theories regarding the origin and evolution of the universe, as well as for his co-discovery of natural quasicrystals, which expanded the understanding of this unique form of matter. His notable works include the books "Endless Universe: Beyond the Big Bang" and "The Second Kind of Impossible," and he has received several accolades, including the Dirac Prize in 2002 for his contributions to inflationary cosmology.

Name: Craig B. Arnold
info: Craig Arnold was an American poet and professor known for his significant contributions to contemporary poetry. His first book, Shells, published in 1999 and selected by W. S. Merwin for the Yale Series of Younger Poets, marked the beginning of a distinguished career that included numerous accolades such as the Joseph Brodsky Rome Prize Fellowship and the Amy Lowell Poetry Traveling Fellowship. Arnold taught poetry at the University of Wyoming and had his work featured in prestigious anthologies and literary journals. He disappeared in April 2009 while hiking on Kuchinoerabujima, Japan, and was presumed dead following an extensive search. His legacy continues through his poetry and the works inspired by his life, including a collection by his partner, Rebecca Lindenberg.

Name: Joshua D. Rabinowitz
info: N/A

Name: Roberto Car
info: Roberto Car is an Italian physicist and the Ralph W. Dornte *31 Professor in Chemistry at Princeton University, where he also contributes to the Princeton Institute for the Science and Technology of Materials. He specializes in the simulation of molecular dynamics phenomena and is renowned for co-developing the Car-Parrinello method, which integrates quantum mechanical density functional theory with molecular dynamics. Car has received numerous accolades for his work, including the Dirac Medal, the Aneesur Rahman Prize, and the Benjamin Franklin Medal in Chemistry. He is a member of the National Academy of Sciences and has held various academic positions throughout his career, including roles at the University of Geneva and the Fritz Haber Institute of the Max Planck Society.

Name: Harrison Hong
info: Harrison Hong is the John R. Eckel Jr. Professor of Financial Economics at Columbia University, recognized for his significant contributions to the field of financial economics. He received the Fischer Black Prize in 2009 for his original research relevant to finance practice. Hong earned his B.A. in economics and statistics from the University of California, Berkeley, and his Ph.D. in economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. His research focuses on behavioral finance, asset pricing, market imperfections, and decision-making biases. Prior to his current position, he was the John Scully ’66 Professor of Economics and Finance at Princeton University.

Name: Andrea Goldsmith
info: N/A

Name: Naveen Verma
info: N/A

Name: Jonathan D. Cohen
info: N/A

Name: Pablo Debenedetti
info: Pablo G. Debenedetti is the Class of 1950 Professor in Engineering and Applied Science and a professor of chemical and biological engineering at Princeton University, where he also served as Dean for Research from 2013 to 2023. His research specializes in thermodynamics, statistical mechanics, and computer simulations of liquids and glasses, contributing significantly to the understanding of supercritical fluids, nucleation theory, and the glass transition. Debenedetti has published over 300 scientific papers and authored the book "Metastable Liquids: Concepts and Principles." He has received numerous accolades, including election to the National Academy of Engineering, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and the National Academy of Sciences, and he is currently affiliated with Princeton University.

Name: Gabriele Villarini
info: N/A

Name: Simon Levin
info: Simon Asher Levin is an American ecologist and the James S. McDonnell Distinguished University Professor in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at Princeton University, where he also directs the Center for BioComplexity. He is renowned for his work in mathematical modeling and empirical studies to understand ecosystem patterns and biological diversity. Levin's influential contributions include his highly cited paper "The Problem of Pattern and Scale in Ecology" and his editorial work on the Princeton Guide to Ecology and the Encyclopedia of Biodiversity. He has received numerous accolades, including the National Medal of Science and the Kyoto Prize, and is a fellow of several prestigious scientific societies. Levin continues to mentor graduate students and postdoctoral fellows while maintaining an adjunct professorship at Cornell University.

Name: Markus Brunnermeier
info: Markus Konrad Brunnermeier is an economist and the Edwards S. Sanford Professor of Economics at Princeton University, where he also serves as the director of the Bendheim Center for Finance. His research primarily focuses on international financial markets and macroeconomics, with significant contributions to the understanding of bubbles, liquidity, financial crises, and monetary policy. Notable concepts he has developed include CoVaR, the paradox of prudence, and the I Theory of Money. Brunnermeier has received numerous accolades, including the Germán Bernácer Prize and the Smith Breeden Prize, and he is currently the president of the American Finance Association. He is affiliated with several prestigious research organizations and has advised various financial institutions, including the IMF and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Name: Warrren B Powell

Name: Joseph Subotnik
info: N/A

Name: Olga Troyanskaya
info: Olga G. Troyanskaya is an American scientist and Professor in the Department of Computer Science and the Lewis-Sigler Institute for Integrative Genomics at Princeton University. She also serves as the Deputy Director for Genomics at the Flatiron Institute's Center for Computational Biology. Her research focuses on protein function and interactions within biological pathways through the analysis of genomic data using computational methods. Troyanskaya holds a Bachelor of Science in Computer Science and Biology from the University of Richmond and a Ph.D. in Biomedical Informatics from Stanford University. She has received several accolades, including the Overton Prize from the International Society for Computational Biology and election as a Fellow of both the ISCB and the Association for Computing Machinery for her significant contributions to the field.

Name: Paul R. Krugman
info: Paul Krugman is an influential American New Keynesian economist and the Distinguished Professor of Economics at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. He was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences in 2008 for his groundbreaking work in new trade theory and economic geography, which elucidates the patterns of international trade and the geographic distribution of economic activity. Krugman has authored or edited 27 books and published over 200 scholarly articles, with notable works including "International Economics: Theory and Policy." He served as a columnist for The New York Times from 2000 to 2024 and is recognized for his contributions to international economics, liquidity traps, and currency crises. Currently, he is also a Centennial Professor at the London School of Economics and continues to engage with the public through a daily newsletter on Substack.

Name: Alejandro Rodriguez
info: N/A

Name: Gabriel Vecchi
info: N/A

Name: Joseph E. Stiglitz
info: Joseph Eugene Stiglitz, born on February 9, 1943, is an influential American New Keynesian economist and public policy analyst, currently a professor at Columbia University. He received the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences in 2001 and the John Bates Clark Medal in 1979. Stiglitz is recognized for his critical perspectives on globalization and laissez-faire economics, as well as his advocacy for the Georgist public finance theory. He has authored several significant works, including "The Great Divide" and "People, Power, and Profits," and has held prominent roles such as senior vice president and chief economist at the World Bank and chair of the U.S. Council of Economic Advisers. Stiglitz continues to contribute to economic discourse through various initiatives, including the Initiative for Policy Dialogue and his involvement with the Brooks World Poverty Institute at the University of Manchester.

Name: F. D. M. Haldane
info: N/A

Name: Yu Xie
info: Yu Xie is a Chinese-born American sociologist and a professor of sociology at Princeton University. He previously held a distinguished position at the University of Michigan, where he contributed significantly to quantitative methodology, social stratification, demography, and the sociology of science. Xie has authored and edited several key works, including "Women in Science: Career Processes and Outcomes" and "Is American Science in Decline?" He has received numerous accolades, including fellowships from the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the National Academy of Sciences. Xie is also known for his role in directing the China Family Panel Studies, a major social science data collection project in China.

Name: Alexander J Smits
info: Alexander John Smits is an Australian-American engineer and academic, currently serving as the Eugene Higgins Professor of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Emeritus, at Princeton University, where he also directs the Gas Dynamics Laboratory. He specializes in turbulence and fluid mechanics and has contributed significantly to the field through his editorial roles with Efluids.com, the Journal of Fluid Mechanics, and the Journal of Turbulence. Smits was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 2011 and became a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 2020. He received the Batchelor Prize in 2020 for his research contributions and was appointed Officer of the Order of Australia in 2023 for his distinguished service in aerospace engineering and education.

Name: Uri Hasson
info: Uri Hasson is a researcher at Princeton University, focusing on cognitive neuroscience and the study of brain activity related to communication and social interactions.

Name: Robert O. Keohane
info: Robert Owen Keohane is an American political scientist renowned for his contributions to international relations and international political economy. He is best known for his influential book "After Hegemony," which critiques hegemonic stability theory and argues for the sustainability of international cooperation without a dominant power. Keohane has held prestigious academic positions at institutions such as Princeton, Harvard, and Duke, and has been recognized as one of the most influential scholars in the field of international relations. He has received numerous awards, including the Johan Skytte Prize and the Balzan Prize for International Relations, and currently serves as Professor Emeritus of International Affairs at the Princeton School of Public and International Affairs.

Name: Christopher J. CHANG
info: N/A

Name: Rene Carmona
info: N/A

Name: Luca Carloni
info: Luca P. Carloni is a professor and chair of the Department of Computer Science at Columbia University, where he has been a faculty member since 2004. An expert in electronic computer-aided design, he has significantly contributed to methodologies and tools for system-on-chip platforms, heterogeneous computing, and embedded systems. Notably, he developed the Embedded Scalable Platforms (ESP), an open-source platform aimed at simplifying the design of heterogeneous architectures. Carloni has published over 180 scientific papers and received multiple awards, including the Alfred P. Sloan Research Fellowship and the IEEE CEDA Early Career Award. He currently leads the System-Level Design Group and is involved with the Data Science Institute at Columbia University.

Name: Christos H PAPADIMITRIOU
info: Christos Charilaos Papadimitriou is a Greek-American theoretical computer scientist and the Donovan Family Professor of Computer Science at Columbia University. He earned his Bachelor of Arts in electrical engineering from the National Technical University of Athens and his Ph.D. from Princeton University, focusing on combinatorial optimization problems. Papadimitriou has made significant contributions to complexity theory, database theory, and combinatorial optimization, co-authoring influential works such as "The Complexity of Computing a Nash Equilibrium" and the widely used textbook "Computational Complexity." He has received numerous accolades, including the Gödel Prize, the Knuth Prize, and induction into the National Academy of Engineering and the National Academy of Sciences.

Name: Gordana Vunjak-Novakovic
info: Gordana Vunjak-Novakovic is a Serbian American biomedical engineer and University Professor at Columbia University, where she also holds the Mikati Foundation Professorship in Biomedical Engineering and Medical Sciences. She leads the laboratory for Stem Cells and Tissue Engineering and is affiliated with the Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center and the Center for Human Development at Columbia. Her research focuses on engineering human tissues for regenerative medicine, resulting in over 380 scientific publications and numerous patents, and she has co-founded four biotech companies. Vunjak-Novakovic has received significant recognition, including election to the National Academy of Engineering and the National Academy of Medicine, and she was awarded the Sretenje order of the Republic of Serbia in 2021.

Name: Kam Leong
info: N/A

Name: Jingguang G. Chen
info: Jingguang Chen is a Chinese-American chemical engineer and the Thayer Lindsley Professor of Chemical Engineering at Columbia University, with a joint appointment as Senior Chemist at Brookhaven National Laboratory. He is a member of the National Academy of Engineering and has made significant contributions to the understanding and development of novel materials for catalytic and electrocatalytic applications, particularly in bimetallic and transition metal carbide catalysts. Chen has published over 500 peer-reviewed papers and holds more than 20 U.S. patents. His accolades include multiple fellowships and awards from prestigious organizations, reflecting his impact in the field of catalysis.

Name: Yufeng Shen
info: The Shen Lab at Columbia University focuses on human biology and diseases through genomic and computational methods, particularly in computational genomics, human genetics, and computational immunology. Their contributions include developing new computational techniques to identify genetic causes of diseases and understanding immune system dynamics.

Name: David Reichman
info: N/A

Name: Adam Galinsky
info: Adam Daniel Galinsky is an American social psychologist born in 1969, recognized for his contributions to leadership, power, negotiations, decision-making, diversity, and ethics. He currently serves as the Vikram S. Pandit Professor of Business and Chair of the Management Division at Columbia Business School. Galinsky has published over 190 scientific articles and is co-author of the book "Friend and Foe: When to Cooperate, When to Compete, and How to Succeed at Both," released in 2015. He has received multiple teaching awards for his excellence in leadership education and was honored as the Ver Steeg Distinguished Research Fellow at Northwestern University in 2011.

Name: Martin Picard
info: Martin Picard is a Canadian chef, author, and television personality known for his innovative culinary contributions. He authored the book Au Pied de Cochon Sugar Shack, featuring 100 recipes centered around maple tree products. Picard gained prominence through his hosting of the Food Network show "The Wild Chef" and his appearance on Anthony Bourdain's No Reservations, which highlighted his restaurant Au Pied de Cochon in Montreal. He opened a sugar shack in St Benoit de Mirabel in 2009, where he serves unique dishes such as maple pig's head and lobster pie with layers of crème brûlée and almond cream.

Name: Virginia W Cornish
info: Virginia Wood Cornish is the Helena Rubinstein Professor of Chemistry at Columbia University. She earned her BA in chemistry in 1991 and completed her PhD focusing on site-specific protein labeling and mutagenesis. Cornish's research utilizes systems biology, synthetic biology, and DNA encoding to generate specific chemical products from various organisms. She has been recognized with several awards, including the Pfizer Award in Enzyme Chemistry and the Irving Sigal Young Investigator Award. Cornish is also noted for her advocacy for ethical practices in genomic research, particularly in the context of the Genome Project-Write initiative.

Name: Mihalis Yannakakis
info: Mihalis Yannakakis is a professor of computer science at Columbia University, recognized for his significant contributions to computational complexity, databases, and algorithmic graph theory. He earned his PhD from Princeton University and has held prestigious positions at Bell Laboratories and Stanford University before joining Columbia in 2004. Notable for his work on complexity classes such as Max-NP and Max-SNP, he has also advanced the study of acyclic database schemes and non-two-phase locking. Yannakakis received the Donald E. Knuth Prize in 2005 and is a member of the National Academy of Engineering and the National Academy of Sciences, among other honors.

Name: Jonathan S. Owen

Name: Kenneth Shepard
info: N/A

Name: Andrew J. Nathan
info: Andrew James Nathan is a professor of political science at Columbia University, where he has taught since 1971 and currently chairs the steering committee for the Center for the Study of Human Rights. His research focuses on Chinese politics, foreign policy, human rights, and political culture. Nathan has held various leadership roles, including chair of the Department of Political Science and the Weatherhead East Asian Institute. He is an advisor for several organizations related to human rights and democracy and serves on the editorial boards of prominent journals. His notable works include "Chinese Democracy," "The Tiananmen Papers," and "China's Search for Security." In 2013, he received a Berlin Prize Fellowship at the American Academy in Berlin.

Name: David Kipping
info: David Mathew Kipping is a British astronomer and associate professor at Columbia University, where he leads the Cool Worlds Lab. He earned his MA and MSc degrees in Natural Sciences from the University of Cambridge and completed his PhD in Physics and Astronomy at University College London. Kipping's notable contributions include the discovery of the exoplanet HD 80606b's transit and the founding of the Hunt for Exomoons with Kepler project, which seeks to identify exomoons using Kepler data. He is also known for proposing the halo drive, a novel method of spaceflight, and for his public outreach through the YouTube channel Cool Worlds.

info: N/A

Name: Louis Brus
info: Louis Eugene Brus is an American chemist and the Samuel Latham Mitchell Professor of Chemistry at Columbia University. He is renowned for co-discovering quantum dots, colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals with unique optical and electronic properties, and was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2023 for this work. Brus synthesized quantum dots in solution for the first time in 1982 and developed the Brus equation, which connects particle size to light emission wavelength. His numerous accolades include election to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the National Academy of Sciences, as well as the Kavli Prize for nanoscience.

Name: Wei Min
info: Dr. Wei Min's lab at Columbia University focuses on biophotonics, specifically developing stimulated Raman scattering microscopy and metabolic labeling techniques to study small biomolecule distribution and dynamics in living systems.

Name: Stefano Fusi
info: N/A

Name: Helen H. Lu
info: Helen Haiyan Lu is a Chinese American biomedical engineer and the Percy K. and Vida L. W. Hudson professor of biomedical engineering at Columbia University. Her research focuses on therapies for complex tissue systems, particularly the interface between soft tissue and bone, and she directs the biomaterials and interface tissue engineering laboratory. Lu has made significant contributions to regenerative engineering, including the development of scaffolds for stem cell growth and biomaterials for tendon and ligament regeneration. She has received numerous accolades, including the Presidential Early Career Award in 2010 and election as a Fellow of the American Institute for Medical and Biological Engineering in 2011. Lu has been a faculty member at Columbia since 2001 and has held various appointments in related fields.

Name: Pieter Abbeel
info: Pieter Abbeel, born in 1977 in Antwerp, Belgium, is a prominent professor of electrical engineering and computer sciences at the University of California, Berkeley, where he directs the Berkeley Robot Learning Lab and co-directs the Berkeley AI Research Lab. He is recognized for his significant contributions to robotics and machine learning, particularly in deep reinforcement learning. Abbeel co-founded Covariant, a startup focused on teaching robots complex skills, and Gradescope, an online grading platform used by over 500 universities. In addition to his academic role, he serves as an Investment Partner at AIX Ventures, a venture capital fund investing in AI startups. He is also known for his teaching and for hosting the podcast "The Robot Brains."

Name: Alberto Sangiovanni Vincentelli
info: Alberto Sangiovanni Vincentelli is an academic researcher.

Name: Ion Stoica
info: Ion Stoica is a Romanian-American computer scientist known for his expertise in distributed systems, cloud computing, and computer networking. He is a professor of computer science at the University of California, Berkeley, where he also co-directs the AMPLab. Stoica has made significant contributions to the field, including co-founding Conviva and Databricks, and he is recognized as one of the original developers of Apache Spark and Ray. His research has resulted in over 100 peer-reviewed papers, and he has received numerous accolades, including the ACM Ph.D. dissertation Award and the SIGOPS Mark Weiser Award. As of April 2025, he was ranked among the wealthiest individuals in Romania, reflecting his impact in both academia and industry.

Name: Scott Moura
info: Scott Moura is an academic researcher.

Name: Markita Landry
info: Markita Landry is an academic affiliated with associate professor, chemical and biomolecular engineering, and neuroscience, uc berkeley. Their work relates to engineering.

Name: Alexandre Bayen
info: Alexandre Bayen is an academic affiliated with professor electrical engineering and computer science, uc berkeley. Their work relates to computer science.

Name: Jeffrey A. REIMER
info: Jeffrey Allen Reimer is an esteemed American chemist and academic, currently serving as the C. Judson King Endowed Professor and chair of the chemical and biomolecular engineering department at the University of California, Berkeley. With over 250 publications and more than 14,000 citations, his research focuses on materials chemistry, physics, and engineering, particularly in the areas of environmental protection and sustainability. Reimer has made significant contributions to the fields of electronic materials, gas separations, and NMR techniques, and has authored two influential books on chemical engineering and carbon capture. He has received numerous accolades, including the Humboldt Prize and fellowships from several prestigious scientific societies, and continues to be an active leader in his field.

Name: Yang Yang (楊陽）
info: Yang Yang (楊陽） is an academic researcher.

Name: Paul S. Weiss
info: Paul S. Weiss is an academic affiliated with uc presidential chair, dist prof of chem & biochem, bioeng, and matl sci & eng, ucla.

Name: Dan Geschwind
info: Dan Geschwind is an academic affiliated with distinguished professor of neurology, psychiatry and human genetics, ucla. Their work relates to genetics.

Name: Laurent Pilon
info: The Morrin-Martinelli-Gier Memorial Heat Transfer Laboratory at UCLA focuses on research in heat transfer, contributing to advancements in this field through various publications and academic activities.

Name: Ohyun Kwon
info: Ohyun Kwon is an American chemist and professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, specializing in organic transformations and the development of chiral catalysts. She earned her doctorate from Columbia University, focusing on glycolipid synthesis, and completed postdoctoral research at Harvard University on diversity-oriented synthesis. Kwon's notable contributions include the development of phosphine-based catalysts for asymmetric catalysis and the activation of C(sp3)–C(sp2) bonds in natural products. She has received several awards, including the Novartis Chemistry Lectureship Award and the Arthur C. Cope Scholar Award.
